sections.title: Overview
sections.content: This guide covers creating a new WPILib project in VS Code. WPILib projects can use two main templates: Timed Robot and Command Robot. Timed Robot is simpler and uses periodic methods that run at fixed intervals. Command Robot uses a command-based architecture that organizes code into reusable commands and subsystems.

sections.title: Prerequisites
sections.content:
Before creating a project, ensure you have:

• Visual Studio Code installed
• WPILib extension installed in VS Code
• Your FRC team number ready
• A location on your computer where you want to save the project

sections.title: Creating a Timed Robot Project
sections.content: The Timed Robot template provides a simple structure with periodic methods that run at fixed intervals. This template is good for beginners and simpler robots. The template includes a Robot.java file with all lifecycle methods pre-defined.

sections.title: Timed Robot Video Tutorial
sections.content: Watch this video for a complete walkthrough of creating a Timed Robot project:

sections.title: Step 1: Open Command Palette
sections.content: Open VS Code. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (Mac) to open the Command Palette. This is where you access WPILib commands.

sections.title: Step 2: Start Project Creation
sections.content: In the Command Palette, type "WPILib: Create a new project" and select it from the dropdown. The New Project Creator window will open.

sections.title: Step 3: Select Project Type
sections.content: In the New Project Creator window, choose Template as the project type. This gives you access to pre-configured project templates.

sections.title: Step 4: Choose Programming Language
sections.content: Select your preferred programming language. Choose Java or C++ based on your team's preference. Most teams use Java.

sections.title: Step 5: Select Timed Robot Base Class
sections.content: Select TimedRobot as the base class. This template provides control through a collection of init() and periodic() methods that are called by WPILib during specific robot states.

sections.title: Step 6: Configure Project Details
sections.content:
Enter the following information:

• Team Number: Enter your FRC team number
• Project Location: Choose the folder where you want to save the project
• Project Name: Enter a descriptive name (e.g., "MantikTimedRobot")

sections.title: Step 7: Generate the Project
sections.content: Click Generate Project to create the new robot project. VS Code will generate all necessary files and folders. Once complete, the project will open automatically in VS Code.

sections.title: Step 8: Understanding the Project Structure
sections.content: After creation, your Timed Robot project will have this structure:

sections.title: Timed Robot Project Files
content: src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java - Main robot class with lifecycle methods
src/main/java/frc/robot/Main.java - Entry point that starts the robot program
build.gradle - Build configuration and dependencies
wpilib.json - WPILib project configuration
.vscode/ - VS Code settings and launch configurations

sections.title: Step 9: Understanding Robot.java
sections.content: Open Robot.java to see the template structure. The Timed Robot template includes these lifecycle methods:

sections.title: Timed Robot Lifecycle Methods
content: robotInit() - Runs once when the robot starts
robotPeriodic() - Runs repeatedly (every 20ms) regardless of mode
autonomousInit() - Runs once when autonomous mode starts
autonomousPeriodic() - Runs repeatedly during autonomous (every 20ms)
teleopInit() - Runs once when teleoperated mode starts
teleopPeriodic() - Runs repeatedly during teleoperated mode (every 20ms)
disabledInit() - Runs once when robot is disabled
disabledPeriodic() - Runs repeatedly when robot is disabled (every 20ms)
testInit() - Runs once when test mode starts
testPeriodic() - Runs repeatedly during test mode (every 20ms)

sections.title: Creating a Command Robot Project
sections.content: The Command Robot template uses a command-based architecture. This organizes code into reusable commands and subsystems, making it easier to manage complex robots. The Command Robot framework builds upon the TimedRobot base class by introducing a structure that allows for modular and reusable code.

sections.title: Command Robot Video Tutorial
sections.content: Watch this video for a complete walkthrough of creating a Command Robot project:

sections.title: Step 1: Open Command Palette
sections.content: Open VS Code. Press Ctrl+Shift+P (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Shift+P (Mac) to open the Command Palette.

sections.title: Step 2: Start Project Creation
sections.content: In the Command Palette, type "WPILib: Create a new project" and select it from the dropdown. The New Project Creator window will open.

sections.title: Step 3: Select Project Type
sections.content: In the New Project Creator window, choose Template as the project type.

sections.title: Step 4: Choose Programming Language
sections.content: Select your preferred programming language. Choose Java or C++ based on your team's preference.

sections.title: Step 5: Select Command Robot Base Class
sections.content: Select Command Robot as the base class. This template includes a command-based structure with subsystems and commands.

sections.title: Step 6: Configure Project Details
sections.content:
Enter the following information:

• Team Number: Enter your FRC team number
• Project Location: Choose the folder where you want to save the project
• Project Name: Enter a descriptive name (e.g., "MantikCommandRobot")

sections.title: Step 7: Generate the Project
sections.content: Click Generate Project to create the new robot project. VS Code will generate all necessary files and folders. Once complete, the project will open automatically in VS Code.

sections.title: Step 8: Understanding the Project Structure
sections.content: After creation, your Command Robot project will have this structure:

sections.title: Command Robot Project Files
content: src/main/java/frc/robot/Robot.java - Main robot class
src/main/java/frc/robot/Main.java - Entry point that starts the robot program
src/main/java/frc/robot/commands/ - Folder for command classes
src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/ - Folder for subsystem classes
build.gradle - Build configuration and dependencies
wpilib.json - WPILib project configuration
.vscode/ - VS Code settings and launch configurations

sections.title: Step 9: Understanding Command Robot Architecture
sections.content: The Command Robot template uses a different architecture:

sections.title: Command Robot Components
content: Subsystems: Represent physical parts of the robot (drivetrain, intake, shooter, etc.). Each subsystem manages its own hardware.
Commands: Represent actions the robot can perform (drive forward, collect game piece, shoot, etc.). Commands use subsystems to perform actions.
Robot.java: Sets up subsystems, creates command bindings, and schedules commands based on robot state.
Command Scheduler: Automatically runs scheduled commands and manages their lifecycle.

sections.title: Choosing Between Templates
sections.content: Choose Timed Robot if you're new to FRC programming or building a simple robot. Choose Command Robot if you're building a complex robot with multiple mechanisms that need to work together, or if you want better code organization and reusability.

sections.title: Next Steps
sections.content: After creating your project, you can start adding hardware configuration, writing code for your mechanisms, and testing your robot. Make sure to configure your team number in wpilib.json if you haven't already.
